worklogs.comment:
tianchen92 commented on pull request #6912: ARROW-8020: [Java] Implement vector validate functionality
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6912
 
 
   Related to ARROW-8020.
   
   In C++ side, we already have array validate functionality but no similar functionality in Java side.
   This issue is about to implement this functionality.
   
   see ML discussion
   https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/r5e463275b24dd171cb0347adb8dc10a07d5de97cfa6e023b7806db55%40%3Cdev.arrow.apache.org%3E

+ * Status used for vector and visitor.
+ */
+public class Status {
 
 Review comment:
   I think this might be to close of a copy from C++, I think we should probably throw an exception when a validation error occurs and have validate not return anything.  C++ has a Status class because it doesn't use exceptions (but this isn't idiomatic java).
   
   If you want to clean this up I can do a more thorough review in the next few days.

    */

tianchen92 commented on pull request #6912: ARROW-8020: [Java] Implement vector validate functionality
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6912#discussion_r410092978
 
 

 ##########
 File path: java/vector/src/main/java/org/apache/arrow/vector/ValueVector.java
 ##########
 @@ -283,4 +283,10 @@
    * @return the name of the vector.
    */
   String getName();
+
+  /**
+   * Validate the vector, will throw exception if validate fail.
+   */
+  void validate();
 
 Review comment:
   Thanks for your comments, this is consistent with C ++, and I think it could make code more concise for users. If we remove this, i.e., several cases would looks like this:
   
   if we want to do something like validateFull, one need to write code:
   >VectorValidateVisitor visitor1 = new VectorValidateVisitor ();
   >VectorDataValidateVisitor visitor2 = new VectorDateValidateVisitor();
   >v.accept(visitor1);
   >v.accept(visitor2);
   
   and for ExtentionTypeVector, we need to get underlying vector and call visitor API then
   >VectorValidateVisitor visitor = new VectorValidateVisitor ();
   >v.getUderlyingVector.accept(visitor, null);
   
   Cases above could be can be simplified to v.validate() or v.validateFull() with the two API.
   And I don't insist on this if they are not needed.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

       Instead of adding this directly to ValueVector, can we make a static utility method that does validation and excepts a ValueVector?

issuetype.description: A new feature of the product, which has yet to be developed.
issuetype.name: New Feature

fields.description:
In C++ side, we already have array validate functionality but no similar functionality in Java side.

This issue is about to implement this functionality.
